Publicly criticizing Brown (G) and conducting military exercises (H) can display solidarity but carries a moderate risk of escalation. High-level visits (A), diplomatic negotiations (F), and potential trade agreements (D) can foster long-term stability but seem less urgent given the immediate threat. Actions such as cyber attacks (O), intelligence sharing (J), and increasing surveillance (I) remain reasonable yet secondary responses. Cutting diplomatic ties (L), imposing trade restrictions (M), or engaging in peaceful negotiations (E, F) seem less viable given Brown's aggressive posture. Options such as full invasion (Q), tactical or nuclear strikes (P, R, S) are extreme and not suitable, as they pose severe risks of wider conflict.
